tossups.answer: horse racing [accept answers like being a jockey; accept equivalents like thoroughbred racing; prompt on racing or horseback riding] (The poem is "Inventing a Horse.")

answers: Ólafur Elíasson [accept Ólafur Elíasson]
France [or French Republic; or République française] (The waterfall was installed at the Palace of Versailles.)
Gilbert & George [accept Gilbert Proesch and George Passmore; accept in any orders]
parts: Name this artist who created the multicolored Your Rainbow Panorama in Aarhus. J. M. W. Turner's palette influenced the Colour Experiment paintings by this Danish-Icelandic artist.

In 2016, Ólafur created a waterfall that seemed to emerge from nowhere for a palace in this country. He also created the bright yellow, sunlike Eye See You lamps for a Christmas window for this country’s fashion house Louis Vuitton.

The Louis Vuitton Foundation in France exhibits the series "There Were Two Young Men" by this suit-wearing duo of "living sculptures." These two artists place themselves in intensely colored photo collages of stuff like blood and barbed wire.

answers: Thirty Meter Telescope [or TMT; accept anything about an (extremely large) telescope on Mauna Kea; prompt on Hawaiian telescope or similar answers by asking "where is it specifically?"]
ʻOumuamua ("oh-MOO-ah-MOO-ah") [or 1I/2017 U1]
Chile [or Republic of Chile; or República de Chile]
parts: Name this project delayed since 2014 by Native Kānaka Maoli protesters led by kiaʻi "mountain guardians." Governor David Ige ("EE-gay") faces an impeachment campaign over this astronomical project.
The existing Pan-STARRS telescope array at Haleakala Observatory was the first to sight this shiny and very elongated interstellar object in 2017. Its Hawaiian name means "scout" or "messenger."

This country partly contains the Gemini North and South telescopes that observed ʻOumuamua. Patricio Guzmán's film Nostalgia for the Light uses this country's La Silla Observatory to excavate the buried history of the Pinochet era.

answers: lynching sites [accept equivalents like places where Black (or Mexican-American) people were murdered by mobs; prompt on generic answers such as hanging sites or sites of murders or massacres by asking "who were the victims?"; accept The Lynching Sites Project of Memphis]
Montgomery, Alabama
US Civil Rights Trail
parts: Name these places mapped by Monroe Work Today and a project based in Memphis. A museum founded by Bryan Stevenson uses suspended columns to represent every county in the US containing one of these places.
Stevenson created the National Memorial for Peace and Justice in this city to honor lynching victims. This city's Rosa Parks Museum commemorates its 1955 bus boycott.
Montgomery's Holt Street Baptist Church was one of over 100 sites honored in this 2018 National Park Service initiative. This route stretches through 15 Southern states.

answers: International Booker Prize [or Man Booker International Prize; do not accept or prompt on partial answer]
Celestial Bodies [or Sayyidat el-Qamar]
epistolary novels
parts: Name this prize also won by Chinua Achebe and Lydia Davis before it changed to honor author-translator pairs for a single work. In 2017, David Grossman and Jessica Cohen won it for A Horse Walks into a Bar.
Jokha al-Harthi and her English translator Marilyn Booth won the 2019 International Booker Prize for this novel, which follows three sisters growing up in a modernizing Oman.

Booth accused Penguin's imprint Fig Tree of doctoring her English translation of Girls of Riyadh, a recent work in this literary genre. Modern works in this genre like Julie Schumacher's Dear Committee Members are often composed of emails rather than letters.

answers: homelessness [accept synonyms like being unhoused]
Milwaukee
The Jungle [accept Calais Jungle or Camp de la Lande]
parts: Identify this problem that has been declared a "crisis" in cities such as Seattle. To help deal with this problem, Austin built a village of 180 structures that measure only 200 square feet.
Matthew Desmond moved into a trailer park in this city to examine how frequent evictions could lead to homelessness and other problems for his 2016 book Evicted.

Some 400 homeless people were living in the East Duwamish Greenbelt section of Seattle, better known by this name, prior to a 2016 shooting. Another place with this name originally developed around a Seveso Zone landfill in Calais.

answers: Adam McKay (The Steve Carell film was Vice. The Margot Robbie film was The Big Short.)
Will Ferrell [or John William Ferrell]
Mossack Fonseca & Co
parts: Identify this director fond of breaking the fourth wall, such as his scene of Margot Robbie discussing various financial terms while taking a bubble bath.
McKay co-founded the influential online video site Funny or Die with this actor. He starred as Buddy the Elf in one of the most popular Christmas films of the 21st century.

McKay's The Big Short spawned a mini-genre of "Explainer Movies," including Steven Soderbergh's The Laundromat, in which Gary Oldman, Antonio Banderas, and Meryl Streep explain how this real-life Panamanian law firm allowed shell companies of the wealthy to hide their money.

answers: kilogram [or kilo; or kg; accept International Prototype of the Kilogram; accept Ur-kilogram]; do not accept or prompt on other length units like "gram"]

voltage AND current [in place of "voltage" accept V or U or electromotive force or Emf or electric potential difference or electric pressure or electric tension; in place of "current" accept I or amperage; prompt on power or P or wattage by asking "calculated by multiplying what two quantities?"]

wave impedance [or Z; or eta; accept impedance of free space; or Z-naught; or vacuum impedance; or radiation resistance of free space; or characteristic impedance of vacuum; accept input impedance or impedance matching]
parts: Name this SI base unit that, until 2019, was defined by weighing a platinum-iridium cylinder in Sèvres ("SEV-ruh") called "Le Grand K."

Redefining the kilogram based on Planck's constant allows precise measurement of mass using these two quantities. A Kibble balance sets the product of these two quantities equal to (read slowly) little g, times the unknown mass, times its velocity.

The ampere’s 2019 redefinition allowed scientists to directly measure free space’s value of this quantity. Microwave-absorbing materials limit reflection losses by "matching" a coating's "input" value of this quantity to that of the vacuum, using transmission line theory.

answers: sentiment analysis [or opinion mining; or emotion AI; or affect analysis; prompt on data mining or word forms]

dentists [or dentistry; or dental professionals; or dental medicine or oral medicine or Doctor of Dental Surgery; accept orthodontists; prompt on medical professions or doctors or other non-specific answers; accept "The Truth About Dentistry"]
mug shots [prompt on portraits or images of criminals or similar answers]
parts: Name this two-word subfield of natural language processing that classifies the emotional "polarity" of texts. Tasks in this field include detecting agreement and subjectivity.

Online reputation management using sentiment analysis now shapes associate contracts in this industry, whose first Black women included Bessie Delany, a star of the oral history Having Our Say. A 2019 Atlantic article by Ferris Jabr argued that this job's services are often gratuitous.
Reputation management has branched off into extorting people by charging for the removal of these police photos, which are often visible on sex offender locator apps.

answers: Nine-Dash Line [accept Nine-Dotted Line; accept Ten-Dash Line or Eleven-Dash Line; or Jiǔduàn Xiàn; accept Shíduàn Xiàn or Shíyīduàn Xiàn]
sand [prompt on rocks or minerals or soil or mud]
GPS spoofing [prompt on answers like faking their location; accept any answers like GPS manipulation]
parts: Give this term for a series of marks around the Spratly Islands on a map of the South China Sea, which China has used to assert sovereignty over the region.

China has bolstered territorial claims within the Nine-Dash Line area with a "Great Wall" of this substance. Several 2018 articles noted that "the world is running out" of this ingredient for concrete, which is often stolen from riverbeds.

Sand smugglers on the Yangtze River widely engage in this technological technique to avoid detection. Evidence that Vladimir Putin owns an 18th-century palace on the Black Sea comes from the palace's use of this technique.

answers: declawing cats [or elective onychectomy; or equivalents]
sterilization [or spaying; or neutering; or equivalents]
Mars, Inc. (Marathon was the old name for Snickers.)
parts: Identify this medical operation. Veterinarian Alan M. Beck argued that this operation reduces shelter rates by preventing property damage.

Alexandra Horowitz is an advocate for reducing the widespread use of these operations in cats and dogs. Some 31 states have laws requiring that pets adopted from shelters have undergone this operation, which Price is Right host Bob Barker long advocated for.

The growing market for pet care led this company to purchase VCA and its 800 vet clinics in 2017. It also owns the Pedigree lines of pet food, Uncle Ben's Rice, and a food that used to be known as Marathon.

answers: HIPAA ("HIP-uh") [or Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996] (PHI is protected health information.)
fax [or facsimile; or telecopying; or telefax]
HITECH Act [or Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act]
parts: Identify this 1996 legislation co-sponsored by Edward Kennedy and Nancy Kassebaum. Title II of this legislation prevents disclosure of PHI.
This technology is specifically mentioned in HIPAA, leading some doctor's offices to only accept it for sending medical records. This phone-based technology has largely been replaced by email.

This legislation, which was passed as part of the 2009 stimulus, modified HIPAA to require the reporting of data breaches. It also offered billions of dollars for health providers to adopt electronic medical records.

answers: White Trash: The 400-Year Untold History of Class in America
Andrew Jackson
Jon Meacham [or Jon Ellis Meacham]
parts: Name this "400-Year" social history by Nancy Isenberg that traces perceptions of poor Americans from colonial times to the 2008 presidential election.
The fifth chapter of White Trash discusses the "Cracker Country" of this President, whose replacement by Harriet Tubman on the 20-dollar bill is still pending.

This author drew from the archives at the Hermitage in his biography of Jackson, American Lion. His other studies of the Early Republic include Thomas Jefferson: The Art of Power and American Gospel: God, the Founding Fathers, and the Making of a Nation.

answers: quantum advantage [accept quantum supremacy]
boson-sampling [or word forms; prompt on partial answer]
spheres [accept Bloch sphere; accept 3-sphere]
parts: Identify this two-word phrase for a computational result that Google claimed to obtain in 2019 with an experiment on circuit sampling.

An estimate for the minimum result required for quantum advantage comes from experiments with the photonic implementation of this model of quantum computing. Aaronson and Arkhipov introduced this model of non-interacting eponymous particles.

In boson-sampling, qubit logic gates can be visualized on a representation of this 3-D shape named for Bloch. In 2002, Grigori Perelman proved the Poincaré conjecture, which states that certain 3-manifolds are homeomorphic to a 4-D analog of this shape.

answers: Drawdown: The Most Comprehensive Plan Ever Proposed to Reverse Global Warming [accept Project Drawdown]

educating girls and young women [accept equivalents like girls' education or female education; accept girls' literacy or equivalents; prompt on generic answers about empowering girls or women; prompt on education or literacy or equivalents by asking "for whom?"]
building insulation [or thermal insulation; or word forms]
parts: Name this book that ranks over 100 climate change solutions, edited by Paul Hawken. Jonathan Foley leads the "Project" to implement the policies in this book, which is named for the point at which greenhouse gas emissions start to decline.
Drawdown claims that this goal, combined with voluntary family planning, is the most impactful way to reduce emissions. This is the main goal of charities like Camfed and Room to Read.

Drawdown estimates that 19 gigatons of carbon can be reduced by adding and improving this component of buildings, which prevents unwanted heat gain or loss. R-values measure how effective this stuff is.

answers: Armenian Genocide [accept Armenian Holocaust or similar answers; accept Mets Eghern or Mec Eġeṙn]
Rinderpest [accept cattle plague or steppe murrain]
Conakry, Guinea
parts: Name this event officially recognized by Congress in 2019. Elif Shafak has been prosecuted under Article 301 of the Turkish Penal Code for recognizing this historical event.

Recognition efforts for the Armenian Genocide inspired a reparations campaign for Namibia's Herero and Nama genocide, which was exacerbated by an outbreak of this livestock-borne disease. It was eradicated in 2011.

Herero and Nama deaths on Shark Island were comparable to the thousands of political prisoners starved on a "black diet" in this city's Camp Boiro. This city endured multiple general strikes in 2006 after President Lansana Conté released two allies from prison.

answers: The Killers
Bruce Springsteen [or Bruce Frederick Joseph Springsteen; accept "The Boss"]

Georgia and South Carolina Sea Islands [accept specific Sea Islands such as Saint Helena Island or Jekyll Island or Hilton Head Island or the Golden Isles; prompt on coastal South Carolina or SC or coastal Georgia or GA; prompt on Lowcountry; prompt on Atlantic Coast; do not accept or prompt on "South Georgia and the Sandwich Islands"]
parts: Name this post-punk revival band that collaborated with Lou Reed on "Tranquilize," a song collected on their album Sawdust along with their cover of Joy Division's song "Shadowplay."
The Killers' album Sam's Town was largely inspired by this artist, whose E Street Band was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2014 on the strength of songs like "The Ghost of Tom Joad."

On his album We Shall Overcome, Bruce Springsteen performed folk songs popularized by Pete Seeger, including "Pay Me My Money Down," a stevedore ("STEE-vuh-dor") working song from this place. This place is the main setting of Julie Dash's 1991 film Daughters of the Dust.

answers: young adult crossover [accept crossover episode; prompt on cameo]
Jacqueline Woodson
Thirteen Reasons Why
parts: This publishing industry term refers to teen books that are simultaneously marketed to adults. This word also describes an episode that involves characters from one TV show interacting with characters from a different show.

This author crossed over to writing adult fiction with her recent novels Red at the Bone and Another Brooklyn. She earlier fictionalized her Civil Rights-era childhood in the verse novel Brown Girl Dreaming.

Woodson's young adult books have often appeared on the ALA's annual Banned Books List. This young adult novel by Jay Asher centering on some tapes recorded by Hannah Baker appeared on the list in 2012 and then again in 2017 following a controversial TV adaptation.

answers: reindeer [or caribou; or Rangifer tarandus; prompt on deer or ruminants or other non-specific answers]
plant seeds [accept seed vaults]
Aleppo [or Ḥalab; accept Aleppo pepper] (Hatay Province is in Turkey.)
parts: Name these animals targeted by mass culling and vaccination campaigns to prevent their carcasses from spreading "zombie" strains of anthrax. These animals increasingly face starvation as warmer weather forces them to eat seaweed instead of lichens ("LIKE-ens").
In 2019, climate change caused hundreds of reindeer in Svalbard to starve. Svalbard is also home to a global vault for these things to help preserve agricultural biodiversity.

In 2015, researchers requested hardy wheat and barley seeds from Svalbard to restock a damaged seed bank in this city. A red spice named for this city is now mainly exported from Hatay Province in a neighboring country.

answers: African-American Vernacular English [or AAVE; or AAE; or Black English Vernacular or BEV or Black Vernacular English or BVE; accept Ebonics; prompt on American English]
John McWhorter [or John Hamilton McWhorter V]
pied-piping
parts: Identify this dialect that was controversially classified as a Niger-Congo language in a 1996 resolution by the Oakland Unified School District that approved its use for instruction.

This prolific creole linguist championed AAVE's uniqueness in Talking Back, Talking Black. This author of Our Magnificent Bastard Tongue: The Untold History of English hosts Slate's secretly-showtunes podcast Lexicon Valley.

One of McWhorter's opponents in "the creole debate," Salikoko Mufwene ("moo-FWEN-ay"), has noted that spoken English dialects like AAVE tend to lack this type of wh-fronting ("W-H-fronting"), in which extra words like prepositions are moved along with interrogative words. It occurs in the example phrase "the fork with which I ate" but not "the fork I ate with."

answers: The Vory [or vory-v-zakone; or thief in law; accept The Vory: Russia's Super Mafia]
Dagestan [or Republic of Dagestan]
tattoos [accept tatau or malu or pe'a]
parts: Identify this "Russian super mafia" whose members were opposed to the suchya ("SOOCH-ya") of the Soviet gulag system.

Galeotti documented the close ties between the Vory and Said Amirov ("sa-EED ah-MEER-ohv"), the longtime ruler of this republic's unruly capital of Makhachkala. Ibn al-Khattab was one of the warlords who invaded this polity in 1999.

The Vory distinguish themselves from other members of society by having highly visible objects of this sort. Sāmoan priests often sanctify the spaces where masters called tufuga spend up to two weeks "tapping" one of these artworks.
